newsitem.title: UK: Belfast court attack dampens N Irish peace hopes.
newsitem.headline: Belfast court attack dampens N Irish peace hopes.

text.p: A daylight IRA missile attack on Belfast's main courthouse has further dampened hopes of renewed peace in Northern Ireland, with fears that progress will only be possible after a British general election.
Monday's attack was the first time that the guerrilla Irish Republican Army have struck at the heart of the province's capital since it ended an 18-month ceasefire last February.
"The genie in many ways is now out of the bottle...we are living once again in dangerous times," Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the IRA's political arm, told BBC television.

The IRA earlier admitted it had carried out an attack in which an improvised grenade was launched out of the window of a stolen car as it sped past Northern Ireland's Courts of Justice slightly injuring a policeman and a civilian.
It gave an apparently hoax warning that it had planted six bombs in hotels and transport termini, causing the security forces to carry out checks. However, they found nothing.
Sinn Fein's chief strategist, Martin McGuinness, made clear that republicans see little prospect of renewed peace while the present British prime minister remains in office.

"The most constructive contribution that John Major could do tonight towards a search for peace in Ireland is to call an immediate British general election," he said in a British independent television interview.
"We need a new government in Britain, we need new imagination."
McGuinness was immediately accused by unionists who support British rule over Northern Ireland of trying to force Major to call an early poll.

"It appears from the words of Martin McGuinness that the IRA are engaged in a campaign the objective of which is to force a general election," said Gary McMichael, leader of the Ulster Democratic Party (UDP).
The UDP has links with a loyalist guerrilla group, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, which McMichael said would maintain its ceasefire for the moment despite IRA provocation.
Major must call an election by May 22, but none of the main British political parties want Northern Ireland as a poll issue.
They all agree the IRA must lay down its arms before Sinn Fein can join in talks on the future of the province.

Monday's attack, which followed the discovery last week of a vehicle on the outskirts of Belfast containing 1,000 pounds (450 kg) of explosives, was condemned by the British, Irish and U.S. governments, who have been working together to promote peace.

British Northern Ireland Secretary Sir Patrick Mayhew accused Sinn Fein of "honeyed words and hard deeds" and said it could not join other Northern Irish parties in talks until the IRA renounced violence.
"Each gangster crime of this kind only serves to reinforce their self-imposed exclusion," he said.
Irish Prime Minister John Bruton said: "These actions once again call gravely into question the true long-term intentions of the IRA."
In Washington, State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns, referring to Monday's attack and other recent events, said: "These incidents have shaken the fragile peace in Northern Ireland."
